author: pcam77

title: N scale Code 70 track 172mm length with modular bed and dam

description.text:
This design is a fully modular railroad track with track bed and some railroad embarkment. Total length is 172mm which gives you a nice display for European locomotives.

There are four different catenary supports available for this design: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1593251

It is designed to be a showcase stand for your rolling material but feel free to remix it to support conducting rails.

Printer:

Dremel Idea Builder

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.15mm

Infill:

10% rectangular

Notes:

Layer heigth: 0.15mm;
Initial layer: 0.25mm;
Nozzle: 0.4mm;
Wall strength: 3;
Speed: 80mm/s;
Material: PLA, 3dk.berlin aluminium silver metallic, 3dk.berlin bronze, Dremel green transparent;
Temperature: 220°C

How to fit the catenary supports...

First decide which type of mast you will use, there are two variants. One type is fixed vertically in the embarkment, the other is fixed below the track bed.
Then use an appropriate tool to cut away the material which is covering the hole or slot you will be using.

Rail shape

The rail uses Code 70 dimensions (more exactly, it is designed as Profile 18 rail according to NEM 120). Since Code 70 cannot be printed properly with a 0.4mm nozzle, the rail does not feature the slim waist in the middle. This waist is present in the included design file, if you would like to remix. So the rail resembles ARNOLD or Hornby tracks and can be sliced and printed robustly this way.

Track, track bed and embarkment design

Again, this follows the dimensions given in NEM standards, in this case NEM 110 and 122.

The sleepers are sized like standard wooden sleepers, the real-life distance was around 60cm which is normally used for concrete sleepers, according to wikipedia. Update: actually, 60cm would be the grid for the sleepers, not the distance between them. So this design ends up having a 96cm grid for the sleepers in real life, not suitable for high speed or high load traffic. However, it makes the rails look smaller.

The rail fixtures have been estimated from photos and optimized for slicing and printing.

The gravel of the track bed is sized to be printable with a 0.4mm nozzle in one line. It is therefore not to scale.

title: 40mm Fan Shroud for Metal Plus with E3D v6

description.text:
UPDATE: I noticed that too much air was blowing on my nozzle, causing a bit of excessive nozzle pressure. So I revised the design to add for more air flow at a downward angle.

UPDATE: I also added a version that is 22mm in height for those of you that are vertically challenged. Please note, I have not tested this version for air flow as it was only created upon request from another member on this forum.

This is a new fan shroud for the Printrbot Metal Plus when using the E3D V6 hotend, coupled with the factory PB Alu Extruder Block. It utilizes the original 40mm fan that was supplied with your printer, but requires that you find new M4 screws at ~11mm in length (I just ground some longer ones down with my Dremel) to mount the shroud.

You will need to space the extruder block away from the X Carriage in order to mount the E3D directly to the factory block. I have added the STL file that I used from bluecoast: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:37608

Side Note: The first time turning the fan on I noticed that the blades were barely contacting the PB mounting plate, making a buzzing noise. So I took a bit of 220 grit sandpaper, and with the blades spinning, lightly touched the sandpaper to them until they no longer made a noise when mounted. Just a tip if any of you have a similar issue.

Feel free to leave any comments or suggestions.

Enjoy!

Printer Brand:

Printrbot

Printer:

Printrbot Plus

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2 mm Layer Height

Infill:

title: N scale modular track catenary masts

description.text:
Four types of catenary masts that fit to this thing: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1593126

The masts called "dam" are mounted vertically in the embarkment, the masts called "track" slide under the track bed.

The "pull" masts mimic line tensioning masts, in this case with internal weights.

Please note that the height of the catenary matches model railroad standards. That means if you use the masts as decoration on an electrified model railroad, you mustn't extend any pantographs or they will collide with the catenary supports.

Notes:

Try to make your slicer produce a first layer as shown in the image, with mostly uninterrupted lines. For my slicer, I had to rotate the object 90° on the build platform.
If the following layers do not slice the catenary support with 0.8mm width, i.e. two lines of extruded filament for a 0.4mm nozzle, try to scale up by 1%.

title: Aether Bull: Goblin Aether Ship (18mm Scale)

description.text:
The Aether Bull is designed to be a big play set and is, really, more terrain than anything. However, it can most definitely be used as part of a larger battle with it's own stats. The goblins and hobgoblins are either straight from Dutchmogul or derivatives of his goblins and hobgoblins.

This was a commitment to print. It took about 120 hours of print time, but I think it'll be worth when I get to finally crash toys using the Bull as a backdrop and, eventually, as a unit in a larger game.

I created the Aether Bull for Wayfarer Tactics. I'm really not sure if it'd work as designed in another scale, but I may re-work it down the road for 15mm scale. For now, I'm done working on it and want to play!

Also, we've set up a Patreon page for anyone who'd like to support us in keeping our toys open source.

Thank you for looking, happy gaming!

remixed_from.author: geoffd123
remixed_from.title: Prusa Mendel Adjustable Z-opto end stop

title: Adjustable opto holder with space for the wires

description.text:
The default opto mounting brackets for the Prusa Mendel don't mount opto stops very well.  Or at least not the ones I have, which have wires coming out the back.  
I like how Geoff has the orientation, but don't want to bend the leads on the opto stop.  
This allows the opto holder to be mounted flat on the bracket with screws and allows the leads to feed down without bending.  It is also one piece to mount the stop.
I used springs between the opto stop and bracket so I could make fine adjustments more easily.  Trying to slide the stop up and down the rod a specific amount is a challenge.
The printed end stop I know I saw someone else on Thingiverse make one just like it, but I couldn't find it again.  If you let me know which it is, I can give them proper credit.  It mounts to the end of the X smooth rod.  If your filament isn't optically opaque, wrap it with foil.  
This will be a lot more resistant to damage caused by hitting it than strips of foil.

I used M3 screws and nuts for mounting the stop.  The springs were ones I got in an assortment pack so I don't know what size they are, other than they fit over the M3 screws nicely.  I used an M4 nut and screw to hold the stop in place on the smooth rod.
The holes on my opto stops are 19mm (on center) apart so the holes are spaced for that.
I posted the SCAD file so you could easily make adjustments. The opto end is offset to one side because of the placement of my flags.  
Update, I uploaded the STL files.  Sorry I forgot that at first.

This part wipes the filament off the extruder before the print begins. It's a simple design that is made for a brush, but also works very well if a staple or wire which will complete the same task.

The G-code needed to run it is a simple five lines of code. You need to copy and paste the lines below before the printer prints a test line. If you use Slic3r, you can just add it to the 'start G-code'.

G1 X146 Y-20 Z11 F9000
G1 X146 Y20 Z11 F9000
G1 X146 Y-20 Z11 F9000
G1 X146 Y20 Z11 F9000
G1 X100 Y-73 Z11 F9000

It can be printed at 0.20 mm and with no supports.

description.text:
Brief instruction

I run OpenSCAD 2016.03.10.nightly in Devuan Linux. I recommend OpenSCAD 2015.03.

OpenSCAD 2015 introduced font handling function text(). I used it to generate 3D numbers in letter_vertex() module as you see.

module letter_vertex(s1=5, letter, p, p_offset=5, c1="black")
{
x = abs_add(p[0], p_offset);
y = abs_add(p[1], p_offset);
z = abs_add(p[2], p_offset);
translate([x, y, z]) color(c1) rotate([90, 0, 45])
linear_extrude(height=0.5, center = true, convexity = 10, twist = 0)
text(letter, size=s1, font="Courier");
}

build_dome_parts.scad is main program. Other scad files are dome data files.
pydome_sorted.scad is for the freqency 10 dome.

include ;

To create a frequency 2 dome, put dome_r30_f2_v38.scad in the <> and press F5.
It will generate a simple dome.

include ;

Naming convention of dome data file

r30 is radius 30.00
f2 is frequency 2
v38 is numbe of vertices is 38.
dome_r30_f2_v38.scad

I've been porting Geodome by Edward A. Falk, 2005 to Python 3.x and OpenSCAD.
It is a sample dome generated by pydome. OpenSCAD handles 3D graphic side to produce dome parts.

title: E3D V6 Geetech Prusa i3 Mount

description.text:
This design is to allow the fitment of an E3D v6 hot end to a Geetech Prusa i3 Pro B although it can probably be used with others if required.

It's designed to mount to the rework x carriage and, for Geetech users in particular, the Geetech customisation of the X Carriage contained in one of my other projects:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1585254

Using the Geetech cutout version of the X-Carriage together with this mount allows the reuse of the original X axis linear bearings, the original Geetech extruder and the original Geetech extruder stepper motor. Even with the addition of the bed levelling sensor this mount, combined with the modified x carriage maximises the available x axis movement.

The OpenSCAD source file allows the mount to be converted to a much simpler Bowden mount and it is this that I will be working further on to accommodate two E3D hot end on the mount, which is why the X axis travel needs to be maximised.

Note that I have created a remixed version specifically for Bowden use which is probably a better option for bowden users...
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2707043

The position of the hot end nozzle on the mount is critical for the Geetech i3 to ensure you also get maximum Y axis travel. If the nozzle is too far out from the X axis then you lose travel at the 0 end and if it's too close you lose travel at the 200mm end. The mount is designed to be optimum for the Geetech Prusa i3 (Acrylic 8mm frame) but this distance is one of the many variables at the top of the OpenSCAD source file to allow this to be matched to your printer.

In addition to the print you will need...

2 x M3x15 bolts and nuts for the hot end clamp
2 x M3 x 30 bolts for the extruder mount
4 x M4 x 20 Bolts and nuts to fix the most to the x carriage.

I use a capacitance level sensor (6-36v 1-10mm) as it works well with the glass bed.

I've also added the .stl file for a cooling fan duct and mount that bolts to the end of the extruder stepper motor and takes the original Geetech 40mm fan from the extruder. It's not the most optimised design but seems to work fairly well. The OpenSCAD file is a bit of a mess at the moment and I'll post it when I get time to clean it up. I printed it as positioned in the .stl file without any supports. Ironically using a cooling fan will improve the print of the duct so the second prototype was a much better print than the second so you might end up having to print this twice, using the first print to cool the second.

Printer:

Geetech Prusa i3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

20%

Notes:

I use Cura and print this with the mounting plate flush to the surface. I use lines rather than a grid for the supports and turns on supports "Everywhere".

It's not an easy print and will need some cleaning up but it's not too difficult for the standard Geetech Prusa i3 to cope with.

Joined the Base Parts on the M2 Spool holder by slipshine to Make it a little more Rigid.  
slipshine Alternative spool holder is awesome! Solved my filament jamming problems. Just found the way it fitted to my M2 made it a little wobbly, so I joined the two lower supports (End-1-L and End-1-R) so they are 1 part with two screws holding them steady. Assembles exactly the same way.

The McLaren MP4/4 was a highly successful Formula 1 car that competed in the 1988 Formula One season. It was designed by American engineer Steve Nichols, with assistance from the team's Technical Director Gordon Murray. For 1988, 16 Races, 15 1st places, 8 for Ayrton Senna and 7 for Alain Prost (wikipedia)

A simple spool holder for the Printrbot Play. It's fully printed except for the crosspiece which is a short length of half-inch PVC pipe. There's plenty of play so lots of pipe sizes should fit.

No are screws needed. The arms clip onto the frame. They're angled slightly inward to keep the pipe in place.

Unfortunately, they're too big to print on the Play. I used a Lulzbot TAZ 5.

This thing is intended to replace the horizontal trim piece on the later hatchback Saab 900s (up to model year 1993), to fit between the trunk latch handle and the inner tail-lights. The original part is connected to the car with steel fasteners through holes drilled in the hatch, which is a frequent water entry and rust point.

Parts are marked for left/right. The original has radiused edges on the top and bottom outside edges, which I will do with a sanding block.

print_settings.Notes:: Use ABS for all parts. Some parts are glued together with ABS + Acetone. For most parts PLA is to brittle. Also you might want to smooth some parts like rotor & stator. I'd like to print with brims to ensure a flat bottom.

description.text:
Tested, works but not suitable for thick materials, like clay. Gears break as they are not running in gears.

Paste extruder, currently testing on my delta printer. It is geared down with 8:13:8:13. It is mounted onto the effector with three screws. A hole pattern on a 40mm circle.

You might want to tweak the rotor a little bit, the model is compensating for error of my 3D-printer (0.4 nozzle). Later i will upload a series of rotor diameters. Also you need to design an adapter to fit it to your printer.

Changes:

  • More reduction: more power.
  • Smaller gears.
  • Moved material inlet to stator.

Tools:

  • Acetone / ABS mixture
  • Acetone for smoothing (optional)
  • Small brush
  • 3 / 4 / 5 / 8 / 10 mm drill
  • Knife

Fasteners:

  • 4x M4x30mm
  • 6x M3x10mm or 16mm
  • 2x M3x8mm
  • M4 Washer 9mm outer diameter x 0,75mm
  • M4 Washer 20mm outer diameter x 1,25mm
  • 8x M3 Nut
  • 4x M4 Nut (1 Nyloc)

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Mendel90

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.25mm

Infill:

40%

Notes:

Use ABS for all parts. Some parts are glued together with ABS + Acetone. For most parts PLA is to brittle. Also you might want to smooth some parts like rotor & stator. I'd like to print with brims to ensure a flat bottom.

Cut things away

Cut away all brims, the bottom layers of the print probably sagged due to the heated bed. Correct this. This is extra important for the gears. Oldhamhousing.stl has tree small supports, which also need to be cutted away. 3003moineau_stator.stl has a few unsupported holes which need to be cleaned so M3 Nuts will fit in.

Redrill holes.
  • gearboxeffectormount.stl, effectorgearboxbushing.stl : All 4mm.
  • 3003stator-moineau.stl, oldhamhousing.stl (top holes) : All 3mm, all the way through if you have M3x16 instead of M3x10
  • 3003stator-moineau.stl (material input): 10mm, Careful and slowly, you dont want to hit the inside of the stator.
  • oldhamhousing.stl (bottom holes): 4mm.
  • oldhamrotor.stl, 3003rotor.stl: Choose close to your filament diameter, mine is 3mm. Dont drill through!
  • steppergear.stl: 5mm for stepper shaft. 3mm for M3x8mm setscrews.
  • oldhamgear.stl: 8mm, try cutting the bottom layers first, probably not necessary.
Glue things

Use the ABS / acetone mixture for glueing. Prefit tulein.stl with 3003stator-moineau.stl, if the fit is bad after drilling you might want to sand it down, just put the tulein.stl in your drill and sand it.

Cut a small piece of filament, insert it into 3003rotor.stl and fit oldhamrotor.stl on top of it Make sure the piece of filament is not to long . The piece of filament is ensuring we are centered :)

Optional: glue the effectorgearboxbushing.stl to gearboxeffectormount.stl.

Glue the things and leave them for a minute.

Assemble

Assemble the thing and put some grease on the gears / surfaces with friction. Done.

This is a mobile robot I designed for control theory subject.
The robot contains:

  • 2 parallax continuous servomotrs: https://www.parallax.com/product/900-00008
  • 3 IR distance sensors
  • An Arduino
  • HC-05 Bluetooth module
  • 2 encoders made with http://www.vishay.com/docs/83760/tcrt5000.pdf
  • 2 batteries, one for the servos and the other for the electronics
  • The cluster wheel is made with a marble

It also contains a layer for the electronics (3 non inverter amplifiers for the IR phototransistors).

The idea of the project was to control l it using deep learning networks. For more information you can contact with me: [email protected]

comments.author: McSchweg

comments.text:
Now I know, what your problem is.
You wrote several times, that "lowering the bed by 4 mm would not be possible".
Well, I now remembered, that there was a bad construction error in the kit, when it came from china.
When you go by the instruction provided in their videos or look at the product pictures,
you are ending up with too less space below the heat bed in the middle,
where 4 screws from the belt-locks threaten to touch the bed from below.
My solution:
The carriage of the PCB board consists of three metal plates, combined in an "H"-form. Like |-|.
The "-" is mounted ABOVE the two "|"s. THAT is the mistake (!)
I reversed the order of these parts by turning it 180° and got all the missing space to tighten the bed-adjustment screws all the way down to the minimum of hight. Also, the y-tooth-belt will be more linear by the way for the belt-locks will also be lowered.
Both efects of my rearrangement show me, that there is something wrong with the way, the developers from A-Net have
pre-assembled it and show it all the time in their videos and product-pics.

title: The experiment of Double Cone in the Ramp (O experimento do duplo cone no plano inclinado)

description.text:
The experiment of double cone in the ramp provides counter-intuitive experience.
When the double cone is placed in the begin of the ramp It produces a seeming climb. But in fact, the mass center of the cones falls, only the contact points of the cones climbs the ramp.

This behavior happens because in the begin of the ramp the mass center is on a higer position (higer gravitational energy) than the end of the ramp.

This experiment can be used, mainly, in teaching of center of mass (physics). It is necessary make use of this concept to interpret what is happening.
However it can be used for study torque and geometry because the relation between the object dimensions (the height of the ramp, the inclination angle and opening angle of ramp, the generation angle of cone and its radius) must be related in an appropriate way for produce the seeming climb.

To build the double-cone, print two units of cones and after glue them carefully so that they are properly aligned.
It is recommended at least 30% infill in the cones. But you can print them in different infills to compare the motion between the different mass. If it gets too light maybe it will not rise the ramp because the torque is insufficient to start the movement.

There is two version of this experiment: an small and a big.
The small version is proper to print many sets and give them to students in order to they explain why the double-cone rises the ramp. You also can use this version to print it and use as an ornament in your table.
The big version is useful to teacher do demonstrations in front of class.

[PORTUGUÊS]

O experimento do duplo cone no plano inclinado proporciona uma experiência contra intuitiva. Ao colocá-lo na parte mais baixa da rampa, no início, o cone produz uma aparente subida, mas na verdade seu centro de massa "cai", apenas os pontos de contato do cone com a rampa é que sobem.

Tal comportamento se deve porque no começo da rampa o centro de massa do cone está numa posição mais alta (de maior energia potencial gravitacional) do que no final da rampa.

Este experimento pode ser utilizado no ensino do conceito de centro de massa, pois se faz necessário lançar mão desse conceito para interpretar o quê está acontecendo. Contudo, ele também pode ser utilizado para o estudo de torque e geometria, pois a relação entre as medidas dos objetos (ângulo de inclinação e da abertura da rampa, o ângulo de geração do cone, o raio do cone e a altura da rampa) devem ser relacionados de maneira adequada para produzir o efeito da aparente subida.

Para construir o duplo cone, é preciso imprimir duas unidades dos cones e depois colá-las com cuidado para que fiquem bem alinhadas. É recomendado, pelo menos, 30% de preenchimento nos cones. Contudo, imprimir cones com diferentes preenchimentos pode proporcionar demonstrações diferentes, pois os mais leves subirão mais devagar ou até mesmo ficarão parados devido ao torque pequeno que não é suficiente para iniciar o movimento.

Hás duas versões deste experimento: uma pequena e uma grande.
A pequena é ideal para ser impressos vários conjuntos e entregá-los a estudantes, a fim de que eles tentem explicar o porquê dos cones subirem a rampa. Esta versão pequena também é útil para usá-la como efeite na mesa.
A versão grande é funcional para que professor fazer demonstrações na frente da sala de aula.

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Graber i3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2: cones and the small ramp (cones e rampa pequena) | 0.4: big ramp (rampa grande)

Infill:

Cones: at least (pelo menos) 30%

Notes:

The ramp should be sanded to reduce the friction between the ramp and the cone.

RECOMMENDATION: print the cones one each time to avoid dripping.

=> PORTUGUÊS:
Pode ser necessário lixar a rampa para reduzir o atrito dos degraus que se formarão durante a impressão.

RECOMENDAÇÃO: Imprimir um cone de cada vez para evitar gotejamento.

Papers used for study the mathematics of this experiment (Artigos utilizado para estudar a matemática deste experimento)

Desvendando o mistério do duplo cone. (Uncovering the mystery of the double cone)
MEDEIROS, Alexandre and MEDEIROS, Cleide Farias de.
Rev. Bras. Ensino Fís. [online]. 2003, vol.25, n.3, pp.333-339.
Available from: http://www.scielo.br/scielo.php?script=sci_arttext&pid=S1806-11172003000300011&lng=en&nrm=iso

RELATÓRIO FINAL: DUPLO CONE (Final report: double cone)
Ceron, Sarah Vergueiro.
UNIVERSIDADE ESTADUAL DE CAMPINAS INSTITUTO DE FÍSICA “GLEB WATAGHIN”. 2009.
Available from: http://www.ifi.unicamp.br/~lunazzi/F530_F590_F690_F809_F895/F809/F809_sem2_2009/SarahV_David_RF1.pdf

A Flash Gordon-esque steering console to keep your mission on course.  1:18 scale.

I added some detail to the rings on the base with a sliver paint pen.  Assemble base, top and trim with acetone or glue.  Pop steering wheel into place.

description.text: This is a tooth brush holder for two Oral B brushes lasered from 2 mm acrylic. The groove to prevent the brushes from slipping out are made by laser engraving. I can't give any advise concerning settings, you have to try it out a little bit. You need six rubber rings 6 x 2 mm to keep it together. They are applied to the middle pins. Use the PDF for cutting.

comments.text: Hello Maker community, I need your help. I could not find suitabke rubber rings yet. Those I use know have a outer diameter of 6 mm and 2 mm in cross section. They consist of NBR-70 and are desinged for sealing different kinds of pipes and fitting in industry. The problem is that as soon as I force them to be in a different shape than round they start to get little cracks, where they are streched around the edges of the lasered pins. First I use some cheap ones that even broke after a few days. A good material might be silicone, but I can't find them in the dimension I need. Does anyone know, where to get those rings?

title: Simple cable anchor
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
This is a simple brad nail based cable anchor for shielded cables up to 5mm in diameter, you can use larger cables if you don't mind preloading/compressing them.

I have included both a single and dual cable model.

I included a recess to avoid getting hands and clothing torn by exposed brad heads. If you would like to use a larger fastener, ream appropriately. If you would like an additional change, post it in the comments, I will add more versions by request.

title: V2 WATER FUEL Stan Meyer Water Cell Housing Pipe Inner Diameter 4" Compatible 7 Tube Sets
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
2016-10-24 - See http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1848291 for a model that can be fully enclosed in 4" pipe.

2016-06-03 - Updated file to make top diameter 1.5mm smaller to better fit ID of 4" pipe.

2017-09-04 - New version that cuts out some of the center to reduce print time / material. Shouldn't have any negative effect on function.

This version is designed to correct a few printing related deficiencies.

  1. No more bridging
  2. Hollowed from the bottom. If the print isn't completely water tight, this can be filled in with some kind of filler to seal the tubes. I'm hoping this to be easier to seal up if there is any printing related leaks.
  3. Removed a lot of excess area to save print time and plastic.

Issues I have been having with printing:

  1. Several micro leaks between layers. Leaks very slowly. If you know how to print without leaks or a suitable and inexpensive way to plug leaks, please let me know.

A cell housing for 7 tubes for a water fuel cell. I designed it to be size compatible with 4" inner diameter clear pipe.

Tubes it is designed for:
Outer diameter of outer tube 1"
Outer diameter of inner tube 3/4"

Outer tube is 77mm long.
Inner tube is 90mm long.

These are NOT the dimensions of Stan Meyer's tubes!

I make no claims whatsoever as to effectiveness, fit or suitability. This is here simply for interest sake.

I recommend having wall thickness >1mm when printing. The holes for the contacts are 5mm in diameter, to be tapped for M6 screws. I have also made some nicer caps.

Printer:

Modified Cobblebot

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

15%

Notes:

Thicker walls/shells recommended. I use 6 layer perimeters/shells.
PLA NOT recommended. PETG or ABS preferred.

I printed with 0.4mm nozzle and still had micro leaks printing with PETG. Perhaps printing with a wider nozzle may reduce leaks?

100% infill may reduce chances for leaks although increase print time obviously.

This is a long print. Could take 35 hours or longer. Mine printed in 37 hours.

description.text:
This are a new motor mount for the Brushed Sparky. I made this because the original do not fit very good. The original was not tight enough. Also the original landing gear I could not mount because they broken at mounting.
So I design a new one. The landing gear and motor mount will srew with 2 M2 screws. I make a thread in the landing gear so i don't need a nut. You can also drill the hole a little bit bigger and use a nut.

there are two motormount files:

  • one is named motormount-85: With 8,5mm hole
  • one is named motormount-88: with 8,8mm hole

I had to print with a 8,8mm hole because my printer prints the holes 0,3mm smaller. I do not know how it is on other printer so i uploaded 2 versions.
The original motors have 8,5mm diameter.

I also uploaded the STEP files so you can easy modify the things.

author: odwquad

print_settings.Notes:: PLA.: - Temp: ~196 degree - Speed: 33mm/s

description.text:
This small and simple printable tool for Ultimaker 2, will help in aligning the two rods of an axis (X or Y).

At the printer to be checked:

  1. Loose the screws of all tooth-drives for an axis.
  2. Connect simply the rod 8mm (slides) and the rod 6mm (print Head), with at least two Align tools, one at each end.
  3. Turn the screws firmly again, and then remove the Align tools.
  4. Repeat the action for the second axis.
  5. Done...

Printer Brand:

Ultimaker

Printer:

Ultimaker 2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1mm / Nozzle-Size: 0.4mm

Infill:

33%

Notes:

Important: Print two, four, or more Align tools on a perfectly aligned 3D printer!

PLA.: - Temp: ~196 degree - Speed: 33mm/s
I have the Align tool made for a quick and easy verification of the X- / Y-alignment, and for fixing the print-head for further maintenance. For more accurate results please use professional tools.

description.text:
This is the Mustang pony emblem scanned and cleaned up with Fusion360 for 3D Printing. The printed size is very close to the original emblem on the Ford Mustangs from the 1960's.

From the pictures above, the large emblem is at 100% and the smaller one is at 50%. I printed these examples at .2 mm.

Update: I've uploaded a vertical version of the emblem. Please print with Brim and Supports. The result is much better than laying flat.

Geeetech Aluminum Prusa i3

No

No

Resolution:

.20

<= 50%

Notes:

Infill and resolution are at the user's discretion. I used 50% infill and .20 resolution for the examples above..

I scanned an original 68 Mustang emblem with Reconstructme and cleaned the mesh up with Meshmixer and Meshlab. The bars didn't come out well so I edited them out and designed new bars close to the original dimensions and overlay the pony emblem onto them using Fusion360 and sent the model into Netfabb Cloud for cleanup.

title: Popplio - Pokemon Sun & Moon Water Starter

description.text:
Please watch this video for more information: https://youtu.be/ufz8foj4Xs8

It's finally time for the 3rd and final Pokemon Sun & Moon Starter. This is the Water Type Popplio. I created this model in Fusion 360 using the sculpting tools in there. Then I added the details using sketches. It took about 4 hours to model and another 7 to print.

Print Settings:
Printer: Robo 3D R1
Filament: Hatchbox White PLA
Layer Height: 0.1mm
Infill: 20%
Supports: Yes
Raft: Yes

Post Processing:
Step 1: Remove all supports and clean up any rough areas with sand paper or a file.
Step 2: Apply a primer. We used automotive fill primer to help fill in the print lines as much as possible.
Step 3: Paint it! We used water based acrylic paints with a paintbrush to apply the paint. Start with the blue on the body then move to the smaller details.
Step 4: Let dry and enjoy!

I hope you like this. Let me know what you think. :)

title: Frontwheel assembly for Navibot robotic vacuum cleaner

description.text:
Front wheel for Samsung navibot robotic vacuum cleaner.
These things sometimes fall off or are lost.
Here is a replacement so you don't have to spend $50 if you need one.
Printed in place, designed in such a way that the hinged turntable can move left and right without using any screws. In case if it doesn't print well or breaks you can use one screw instead to keep the vertical axle in place.

I attached the whole assembly to the robot with a foam double sided sticky tape. Works really well!

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.22mm

Infill:

25%

Notes:

The horizontal axle is really small, printed with brim, as on the picture above.
Others are without brim or support.

Problem

You know what happens when a $500 robotic vacuum cleaner looses it's front wheel?
The whole assembly for that matter, not just "the" wheel.
It means two options:
A: throw the whole thing away worth $500
B: buy the wheel assembly from Ebay or similar and spend $50

Solution

But wait: there's option C too:

Print one!

So i did.
Designed with Blender. Printed with PLA. Works really great!

Bonus

Unlimited supply of extra wheels in a matter of minutes if your robot ever happens to loose one!

This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/eD6nhVH0kxv

OpenSCAD rhombic triacontahedron tile with holes for magnets.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rhombic_triacontahedron

You'll need to print a total of 30 tiles, and 4 disc magnets per tile (axially magnetized). That's 120 magnets in total. I bought mine on eBay in bulk and used superglue to secure them in the tiles.

See the User Defined Variables section of the OpenSCAD script for the parameters you may want to change (magnet holes and overall size of tile, total 4 parameters). Or just use the pre-built STL with 6mm diameter magnets.

Not familiar with OpenSCAD? It is easy to obtain and use! Download it here: http://www.openscad.org. After installation, open up the OpenSCAD file for this thing and hit F6 to render (or use the menu options up top). File->Export as STL and take it to your slicer!

These are also on github: https://github.com/eshira/polyhedra

Magnet Orientations

Magnet orientation:

Parallel sides have the same polarities facing out.
Adjacent sides have opposite polarities facing out.

For example, make the top and bottom have North facing out, and the left and right have South facing out.

Make sure all tiles have identical magnet alignment!!! A good way to keep track is to make your first tile according to the rules above, and use it as a references for every subsequent tile (test your magnets against it).

title: The Butterfly: lightweight and easy head mount for LM6UU crossbars (eg. Ultimaker)

description.text:
This is a thing in progress b/c of the way the hot ends are attached. This is a generic, minimalist, extremely light, dual-head-ready, two-part only, quick head mount replacement for the ultimaker. I am using it most of the time in place of the stock mount. It can be used like this but there is also some work/upload to be done for a better attachment to the hot ends (see the instruction for more). See, eg. the specific mount for the E3D on the last picture (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:159987). Should work with almost any 12mm OD bushing/bearing long enough. Once the two parts are assembled together (4 screws) it can be mounted/disassembled in about 1 minute:
  • 2 screws for the electonics PCB on the tob
  • 1 screw to clamp the hot end
  • 1 screw for each bearing, done.
    Check the pictures for the details and how it can be put in place without disassembling the X/Y rods.
    • Just swap it with my reciprocal stock-compatible mount: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:137847 It also has provision for a dual head, even though I never tried so far. For now there is nothing beyond the couplign screws to attach a fan, I am mostly using a separate 120mm fan to blow on my plate (and it works quite well). Check the instructions for more.

Best printed in Nylon, or may be ABS, unless your head is well cooled in which case PLA is OK (I used both PLA and Nylon -- Nylon is a bit elastic, did not notice any impact on the quality though, may be it is even better?!)  
I had it working quite well with miscellaneous hot end.  
The thing is in progress as I test different variations of the mount, as you can see: there is a dedicated E3D hot end mount (last picture), but I sometimes just clamp the push-fit connector itself (see it on the E3D also).  
Grabbing the push-fit is certaily not the best thing to do, because it makes the whole head higher. But it just works quickly for almost any kind of head I want to try.  
WIth a low-profile hot end and/or dedicated attachment, I get a total height which is smaller than the stock one (~1cm shorter), hence less wobble at the nozzle due to the linear bearings. I will post about it another day.

description.text:
An overhaul of my MK8 Extruder Rep2 Mod. Slightly improved ball bearing position and wire spring configuration. I got the best results putting in 2 wire springs. There is, however space for 3 of them.  
This time I included the source files as .step for you to play with/modify/whatever.

What you'll need:
  • a 623 bearing (3mmx10mmx4mm)
  • a 10mm M3 grub screw
  • a 20mm M3 flat head screw (shortened mine to 18mm)
  • a 10mm m3 flat head screw (shortened mine to 8mm)

  • 2-3 wire springs from foldback clips (I used 20mm ALCO foldback clips)

  • a sharp knife, some rasps, manual skills and a bit of patience.
    • I printed with following settings in Makerware: 2 Shells at 100% Infill at 0.15mm layers. Have fun!

print_settings.Notes:: Print The new slider blocks in your favorite color.

description.text:
This design is largely based on the original slider block of Ultimaker 2 (first edition September 2013).

What's different or better?

  • This is not a pure 1:1 copy, but a variant newly created. with the essential features and dimensions from the original!
  • This design is not optimized for injection molding, but for 3D-Print.
  • All snap locks can be opened more easily, so that maintenance work can be performed easily and reliably.
  • When you create a small supply as a precaution, you need not wait for expensive original parts, or cheap China Goods.

Universal use:

  • It is a more universal version available for tension springs with different inner diameter. Then you may need to drill out the leadthroughs, and use a screw. A bolt with nut thus secures the half-shells and keeps the tension spring in position. !!! Choose the screw to match the inner diameter of the tension spring !!!

  • Good for MXL- and GT2-Belts with a maximum width of 6.5mm.
  • Suitable for sliding bearings with the following dimensions: 8mm x 11mm x 30mm. The bearing seat is: 8.5mm x 11.2mm x 30.2mm.

Printer Brand:

Ultimaker

Printer:

Ultimaker 2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1mm / Nozzle-Size: 0.4mm

Infill:

33%

Notes:

Warning:
Possibly a thorough post-processing of each object is required. Remove unwanted deposits from the printed object, such as lint or crumbs. Please pay special attention to the fact that the bearing seats must be absolutely clean for accurate fitment. Failure to comply, the bearings could sit awry, this leads to increased friction and uneven wear.

  • Print The new slider blocks in your favorite color.
  • For a functional object replication can be used almost any materials on the market, including PLA. PLA.: - Temp: ~196 degree
  • Speed: 33mm/s

Because many of my original slider blocks already went during the first dismantling experiment broken.

  • Be very careful if they ever need to open the original slider blocks. The brackets of snap-ins are very brittle!

title: Ultimate FU Bike Handlebar End caps

description.text:
Photo is a custom version with initials, so ignore the BB, but the files included are for a basic hex-head and initials of Frank Underwood (FU).

Print in something sort of flexible, like eSun PET-G. Orient so that the exposed part is up (for nicer finish) and use support.

These are the best fit for carbon bars. If you have thinner aluminum bars, they may be a little loose - but you can just wrap a piece of tape around them before inserting them if needed.

author: rsilvers

title: FX-79 Buffalo FPV Flying Wing Motor Mount

description.text:
These are drawings for a FX-79 Buffalo FPV Flying Wing Motor mount plate.
Cut/CNC those out of 1.5-2mm carbon and glue the no_rim version into the inside of the mount and the rim version on the outside of the mount with epoxy.

Make sure the holes line up.
This will re-enforce the brittle plastic and give you a solid mounting surface for your brushless motor (Holes are equally spaced, leave them out in case your motor has a different mounting pattern and drill suitable ones after the installation).

author: arcmatt

description.text:
This is the first of two remixes I did of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:29677 for a film class I took last month. The other one is here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1594004

For this one the changes are very, very minor. I just made the handles stack together a bit more neatly and it’s made for a camera with a flip out viewfinder so does not need the offset pieces. I also made two sleeves so you can use standard 22.2mm bicycle handlebar grips. I was able to find the foam shoulder pad on TaoBao for about $5 so it did not make sense to print that part. Amazon seems to have similar pads but for a bit more money:
http://amzn.com/B00ENYMQ8I
http://amzn.com/B00OFJMKWS

As in the original you’ll need 15mm and 20mm aluminum tubing, the stuff I used a lot thicker than I needed I think (15mmOD/10mmID and 20mmOD/12mmID). The end plugs reflect this- but you don’t really need them. It just looks cleaner. The thumbwheels are here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:11848 The link to the original model details the required hardware.

Parts list:

2 Piece: DSLR_Shoulder_Rig_handlebar_adapter
1 Piece: DSLR_Shoulder_Rig_close_hand_grip_A
1 Piece: DSLR_Shoulder_Rig_close_hand_grip_B
2 Piece: DSLR_Shoulder_Rig_close_hand_grip_C
1 Piece: DSLR_Shoulder_Rig_simple_rail_spacer
2 Piece: DSLR_Shoulder_Rig_std_clamp
2 Piece: 20mm_end_plugs
4 Piece: 15mm_end_plug
1 Piece: camera_plate_1-4_20 or camera_plate_3-8
